column4: Must read book | Measure your growth
column5:
Before starting this book, write down some good habits you want to build and some bad habits you want to break. This book is filled with practical steps and examples. Yes, there are plenty of habit-building books out there (just as there are plenty of diet books but yet there are still more new books published every year). Plenty of people are seeking the right book that resonates with them. The key points in this book are:
* Compound Effect - Very small changes over time will have a big impact.
* Habit Building Techniques - Make good habits into routines; use positive reinforcements and other techniques outlined in the book.
* Monitor and Measure - Keep track of your progress and improvements.
\n A most practical book on human physiology of habit building and reforming. If want to master your life then you have to master your habits first. and this book will help you to do that.\n

column4: A great book on human behaviour
column5: \n There are some books which are feel good books, and there are books which practical books. Atomic habit is one such insanely practical book which can be applied in life the moment you started reading this book. I remember a similar book I read a few years back 'The Power of Habit' by Charles Duhigg. I would say this book is a easier version than the power of habit book. Concepts are moreover similar in both the books. This book is just written in way so that it's easy to apply the learnings from the book of n daily life. The four key things for forming habits cue, craving, response, reward are discussed in detail in separate chapters. If you are looking for a great book on habit formation read this one first and then you can read 'The Power of Habit' book. Only thing I felt extra and not required is the last one or two chapters. The book could have been shorter. The reason I didn't rate it five star is because already another excellent book has been written on the similar topic by Charles Duhigg\n

column4: Read this summary review and save your money
column5:
This book is written by Jeff Keller who is a motivational speaker, which is evident through the motivational tone of the book. After graduating from law school in 1980, he practiced for a few years. Feeling unhappy with his career in law, he became a motivational speaker which he felt was his true calling. The numerous examples of people who achieved their goals through positive attitude are from his personal experience and research

What do I like about this book?
- The overall motivational tone of the book, that creates a positive drive within yourself
- To-the-point crisp writing, without being verbose at all (unlike some other books which keep reiterating the same points through multiple pages)
- Powerful examples from history
- Great quotes by famous men. It is just a treat to read all these famous words by eminent people.
- The book justifies its title ‚ÄòAttitude is everything‚Äô through its content.

What I did not like about the book?
Well, honestly, NOTHING. I‚Äôm usually critical of books if I find any flaws with the writing, or content, or engagement, but I didn‚Äôt find anything lacking in this one. Hence, the complete five stars. The book is beautifully written with meaningful content.

The book begins with a famous quote by Thomas Jefferson ‚Äì ‚ÄúNothing can stop the man with the right mental attitude from achieving his goal; nothing on earth can help the man with the wrong mental attitude.‚Äù In the first chapter, Jeff Keller talks about his own circumstances that led to his career change, finally becoming a motivational speaker. He mentions general problems faced by common people in their day to day lives and hence creates a bond with the reader.

The book is primarily divided into 3 parts and 12 lessons. Each part includes various lessons, which are thought-provoking. The basic message conveyed through these three parts and lessons is ‚Äì ‚ÄúWhen you THINK, SPEAK, and ACT in ways that support your success, you‚Äôre firing on all cylinders and on the way to achieving phenomenal results in your life.‚Äù

PART 1 ‚Äì SUCCESS BEGINS IN THE MIND: THINKING
In this part, the author tries to teach us that success begins in the mind, and he focuses on the power of attitude and belief in shaping your destiny.

Lesson 1 ‚Äì Your Attitude is your window to the world.
Attitude is like a mental filter through which you experience the world around you. Some people see the world through a filter of optimism while others have a more pessimist outlook. A person with positive attitude thinks ‚ÄòI CAN‚Äô while the others think ‚ÄòI CAN‚ÄôT‚Äô. We all start off with a clean window when we are young, and as we grow old, life throws some dirt on the window (like criticism, ridicule from peers, rejections, disappointments), and we start doubting our capabilities, we start having negative outlook towards thinks, and we are not as confident as we used to be earlier. The advice given in the lesson is to wash our mental window, so we can control our mental attitude. Every human being has the power to choose his attitude. Every human being has the power to choose his/her reactions to different things happening all around.
One of the many Examples cited ‚Äì Dr. Viktor Frankl‚Äôs (Author of Man‚Äôs Search for Meaning ‚Äì would recommend people to read this) experiences during concentration camp.

Lesson 2 ‚Äì You are a human magnet.
The message of this lesson can be summed up in a single quote by Earl Nightingale ‚Äì ‚ÄúWe become what we think about.‚Äù Jeff states the idea of ‚Äòdominant thought‚Äô. He says, your dominant thoughts rule the day. Your beliefs brought you to where you are today, and your thinking from this point forward will take you where you will be in the future. As human magnets, we have the power to attract success through our thoughts. If you think about positive things, positive outcomes, success ‚Äì same shall follow. However, he rightly warns against the expectation of overnight success too.

Lesson 3 ‚Äì Picture your way to success.
The author asks the readers to create mental movies in the mind, picturing things and milestones they wished to achieve. At the same time, we have to get rid of our old rubbish mental images, which remind us of failure, negativity, and disappointments.
One of the many Examples cited ‚Äì Story of singer Celine Dion where she mentions that from the age of five, she had always imagined singing in front of houseful audience, receiving multiple awards and becoming a superstar. Another example quoted is of Jim Carrey, who wrote a post-dated cheque to himself for $10 Million, which acted as a source of inspiration for him.

Lesson 4 - Make A Commitment And You Will Move Mountains.
Jeff mentions the book ‚ÄòThe ultimate secret to getting absolutely everything you want‚Äô by Mike Hemaki. He says, the key to getting what you want is the ‚Äòwillingness to do whatever it takes‚Äô to accomplish your goals. When you commit to something, positive events start happening, the whole universe conspires to make it happen.
He gives the example of Benjamin Roll who cleared the bar council exam in his 14th attempt at the age of 74! Another example cited is that of ‚ÄòBaldacci‚Äô who became a writer, by learning the craft of writing, through sheer commitment.

Lesson 5 - Turn Your Problems Into Opportunities.
Whenever something goes wrong, we start questioning ourselves, our circumstances and at times our luck. In such a situation, we have two choices ‚Äì 1. Keep feeling miserable or 2. Learn a lesson from the problem and move on. A problem should be seen as an opportunity to learn, improve, and do something better next time. Adversity encourages us to make necessary changes in our life, tap our hidden potential. It teaches us to be grateful for the small things and helps us build self-esteem and confidence.
As Napolean said, ‚ÄúEvery adversity carries with it the seed of an equivalent or greater benefit.‚Äù

PART 2 ‚Äì WATCH YOUR WORDS: SPEAKING
In this part, the author focuses on what we speak. What we say, directly shows how we think, and precedes our actions.

Lesson 6 ‚Äì Your Worlds Blaze A Trails.
The author says that words have immense power. They can build your future, destroy opportunities or help maintain the status quo. Your choice of words defines your personality.
Always remember ‚Äì Thoughts > Words > Beliefs > Actions > Results
The author cites an inspirational example of Kent Cullers, a scientist at NASA.

Lesson 7 ‚Äì How are you?
Jeff says that this question is the most frequently asked questions to any person, and what reply a person gives to this question is extremely important. Now, a reply to this question can be ‚Äì Positive, Mediocre or Negative. We should avoid negative answers as they drain the energy of others as well. Jeff says that we should always reply to this question with words such as ‚ÄòTerrific‚Äô or ‚ÄòGreat‚Äô or other such positive words. This will help boost our confidence and create a positive outlook.

Lesson 8 ‚Äì Stop complaining.
Nobody wants to hear about our pains and problems. As William Penn said, ‚Äúthe secret of happiness is to count your blessings while others are adding up their troubles.‚Äù Jeff says that complaining is a major problem in all of us, whereas it doesn‚Äôt help anyone. It doesn‚Äôt help the person ranting about his problems, and definitely doesn‚Äôt help the listener who‚Äôs least interested in listening to someone else‚Äôs problems when he has plenty of his own. However, at the same time, the author clarifies that sharing your problems with your nearest ones, is different from complaining, and rightly so.

PART 3 ‚Äì HEAVEN HELPS THOSE WHO ACT: ACTION
In this part, the author emphasizes on the fact that without action, positive thoughts and words will not help you attain the level of success you aimed for.

Lesson 9 - Associate with Positive People.
We are the average of the people we spend our most time with. The people you hang out with define your outlook and future because they greatly influence our thoughts and life. Hence, it is very important to be in the company of positive people, who have definite goals for themselves. Hanging around folks with no ambition or goals, who imbibe negativity in you, will put you on the path of failure.

Lesson 10 - Confront Your Fears and Grow.
The path that leads to success is often filled with obstacles. The people who succeed, do so by overcoming these obstacles. If you want to achieve something, you have to get out of your ‚Äòcomfort zone‚Äô. You have to stretch yourself. Adopt a mindset that helps you acquire what you want. Remember, repetition is the key, like any other muscle. It will build up and encourage you to do something great.

Lesson 11 ‚Äì Get out there and fail.
Winston Churchill said, - ‚ÄúSuccess is going from failure to failure without loss of enthusiasm.‚Äù In order to success someday, you must be willing to fail today. Successful people around the world are wise enough to know that success doesn‚Äôt come in one shot. You have pe persevere, fail again and again, learn from your failures, and work on it again with double enthusiasm.
The author cites an example of TV talk show host ‚ÄòSally Jessy Raphael‚Äô, who was fired 18 times, couldn‚Äôt pay her credit card bills for 26 years, lived on food stamps, before finally making it big in the industry.

Lesson 12 - Networking That Gets Results.
This lesson shows the importance of teamwork. It shows, if you‚Äôre positive and ready to help people, people, in turn, will go out of their way to help you back. Some key points from this lesson ‚Äì
- Develop a win-win attitude.
- Effectively participate in a group or organization.
- Do not stop the flow of messages, you should keep in touch with your peers.
- Become a good listener.
- Congratulate people on for their accomplishment.
- Make new friends in your field.
- Do more for others, before expecting something in return.

In my opinion, this is one of the best self-improvement books ever written. The content of this book far outweighs its price, and although I have provided the summary for a quick glance, you can still go ahead and pick the book for a quick read. There are many more powerful impactful examples cited throughout the book which make this one an interesting read. Recommended!

Favorite Quotes from the book:
- ‚ÄúEverything can be taken from a man but one thing: the last of the human freedoms‚Äîto choose one‚Äôs attitude in any given set of circumstances, to choose one‚Äôs own way‚Ä¶. Even though conditions such as lack of sleep, insufficient food, and various mental stresses may suggest that the inmates were bound to react in certain ways, in the final analysis, it becomes clear that the sort of person the prisoner became was the result of an inner decision and not the result of camp influences alone.‚Äù
- ‚ÄúWhen you believe you can do something, you have the courage to move forward despite being afraid.‚Äù
- ‚ÄúAs adults, most of us become a lot more concerned about the opinions of others, often hesitating because people may laugh at us or criticize us. At the age of six, we knew we had to fall.‚Äù
- ‚ÄúWhether you think you can‚Äîor think you can‚Äôt‚Äîyou‚Äôre right!‚Äù ‚Äì Henry Ford
- ‚ÄúYou see, when you change your attitude, sparks fly in the universe. You‚Äôre energized. You begin to see new possibilities. You move into action. You achieve extraordinary results. That‚Äôs why I say when you change your attitude, you change your life!‚Äù
- ‚ÄúWhat the mind can conceive and believe, the mind can achieve.‚Äù
- ‚ÄúThey can because they think they can.‚Äù ‚Äì Virgil

Amazon delivery bang on. The binding of pages is not good. For the product I would give 2-3 out of 5. But as the heading suggests it's a book review

Let's start with a fun fact. Do you know this book was published in 1999 when the world was worrying about the Y2K apocalypse, Jeff Keller wrote this gem of a book before entering the modern era of crazy 20th Century.
Attitude is something which is never ever thought in books, it is something which an individual learns and adapts from his/her surroundings. Starting from family, teachers and friends, each and everyone in your life will influence and unknowingly manipulate your thoughts. What the author is trying to say in the book over a course of 12 well crafted chapters is that one has always control of his/her attitude so why not channelize the enter focus of attitude towards positivity and self belief so that we are able to perform to the maximum potential. What I loved about the book was the fact that there were these deep meaningful proverbs and motivational lines written throughout the book quoting famous people so that you read them and feel energized and motivated with same. The author is not afraid to share his story stating how painfully miserable and depressed he was working as a full time lawyer. Something most of us are going through in this state of life wondering is it worth to slog into the office just to realize that in the end it was certainly not worth it. The author has written the book in the most simplest of language and explained some beautiful concepts to change one's attitude from a pessimist to an optimist. Something I will try to implement personally in my life. All in all I would not write anything from the book and potray that I am englightened and changed after reading this book.

What I would say is that, if you are exhausted from daily routine, just take a break from netflix, YouTube, hotstar and what not and read this book. It can do wonders for you and might change your life for good.

column4: This book perfectly serves as a regular dose of motivation!
column5:
This short book ( ~125 pages) by Jeff Keller, a motivational speaker and coach, will show you how to take control and unleash your hidden potential. The book is broadly divided in three parts: Success Begins in the Mind, Watch Your Words and Heaven Helps Those Who Act. Each part is a step by step program further divided into smaller chapters which will definitely help you to change your attitude and your life!

The writing is simple, easy to understand and the author supports his arguments with use cases. The book is very relatable and encouraging. I read one chapter every night before going to bed and this book perfectly served as a regular dose of motivation. Highly recommended to everyone!

column4: If you want to Invest in yourself then its a must buy
column5:
Highest price- 56‚Çπ on 9/8/19
Lowest price- 149‚Çπ on 257/20
Paper quality- average slightly yellow,for better quality paper u can buy penguin publication but it's too pricy
Font size- medium
My rating- 4.8
My opinion- If you want to Invest in yourself then its a must buy
Please give a upvote and follow me if you like it.

Principles of this book
1. Don't criticize,condemn or complain instead try to understand them.
2. Give honest and sincere appreciation
3. Arouse in the other person an eager want (Get the other person's point of view and see things from his or her angle, as well as from our own)
4. Become genuinely interested in other people to let them feel they are important to you
5. Smile
6. Remember that person's name is to that person the sweetest and most important sound in any language
7. Be a good listener. Encourage others to talk about themselves
8. Talk in terms of the other person's interest
9. Make the other person feel important and do it sincerely
10. The only way to get the best of an argument is to avoid it.
11. Show respect for the other person's opinions.Never say, 'you are wrong'.
12. If you are wrong, admit it quickly and empathetically.
13. Get the other person saying a lot of yes' in the beginning of an argument
14. Let the other person feel that the idea is his or hers
15. Try honestly to see things from the other person's point of view
16. An effective way to correct others' mistakes is " call attention to people's mistakes indirectly.
17. Talk about your own mistakes before criticizing the other person.
18. Let the other save face
19. Praise the slightest improvement and praise every improvement
20. Use encouragement. Make the fault seem easy to correct .

column4: One of the most influential books of the century
column5:
Discovering the fact that this text is over 90 years old might push you not to read any further. I urge you NOT to develop this perception that the book doesn't apply to contemporary circumstances. It applies to every generation in the past 500 years. Dale enabled me to perform an in-depth self evaluation. I was able to not only highlight the shortcomings but to rectify them as well. I'd suggest particularly all the introverts out there regardless of wherever you belong to read this book and follow the guidelines.

One drawback, I believe, was the inability to distinguish flattery from "honest appreciation" in cases where an individual is not worthy of praise. Another ordinary factor associated to this book is its title. This provides another instance of "don't judge a book by its cover" hypothesis.

Tell me one thing - what are the attributes that you notice first in a person?

How often do you see a person who is loved by all alike? Rarely, right? No matter how good the person is, there will be something/someone who disagrees with them. Everyone's unique. It's natural to have differences in opinion. BUT what if there's a way to reduce this differences, this gap?

This book comes with answer to the questions we have on human nature and relations- be it in social or business environment. Do you face difficulty in dealing with other people? Do you often feel no matter how hard you try, you are unable to get any results? Are you seeking answers? If yes, give this book a shot.

The author has used simple language throughout the book. If you are new to non fiction, don't worry, you won't have trouble reading this one. (Yup!I'm a newbie)
Things I loved about the book:
1. Division of book - The book is divided into four parts. At the end of each part, a brief summary is given. This helps the reader to revise and recollect the points.

2. Incidents - Throughout the book, the author illustrates examples of how people used various principles and what results it had. This way, a reader can grasp the idea easily.

You may come across concepts you already know, you may find answers you've been seeking. You may end up loving, liking or not liking(slim chance) this book. But let's keep an open mind while reading this book.
If you have read the book, tell me one thing that you learned/would like to try from this book.

column4: Nationalism is a cruel epidemic of evil
column5:
[Chapters]
1. Nationalism in Japan
2. Nationalism in West
3. Nationalism in India
[My Review] :
First time reading Tagore, not as a poet but a political thinker is amazing. A slim, power-packed compilation of Tagore's lectures on the subject of nationalism. Definitely a worth buy specially more relevant with the current scenario of India

When I pickedup this 110-page thin book, I was curious to relate the man‚Äôs thoughts on what nationalism meant, was it good or bad, and what it needs to be like. WRONG! You cannot correlate what the man said on some other podium in some other context in some other land. That needs to be said. Dont draw such parallels. The nationalism of today is very different from that of what he talks about in this book.
The first 2/3rd portion of the book-Nationalism in Japan and America-were specifically said in context with the ongoing WW1 to both nations by the man and are simply utterly boring. He, and I am sorry for my rudeness here, doesn't speak practically or goes to the point in ANY way. I have seen Sadhguru come around to answering a question faster!
There is however some context of how the nationalism was back then in India (circa 1910-30).
Crux of the book is totally inconclusive. You dont arrive at any clear observations from this book. All I can now say is that Tagore ji was an extremely humane person, completely like a sage would be, saying no to weapons and creating borders and what not. But I do know this, he despised Nationalism, imperialism to some extent, the extremists who wanted full freedom. You can seriously get more from the preface that thebook itself!
My advice: put your 100 rupees to better use.
Amazon delivery was speedy and the product is neatly printed and was in excellent condition.
Thanks.

Well, i usually refrain from writing reviews of books online but this one was so amazing that i think it's worth taking out time to write a review for this. That being said, this book is a complete gem. Not only for the knowledge and deep understanding of the nationalism (of Japan, West & India) that it imparts but also the general statements made by Rabindranath Tagore in his speeches about life, machines, human-machines, problems of human races throughout the world & India in pre & post colonial times and the true and real meaning and need of government in today's era.

NOTE: The book is NOT WRITTEN by Rabindranath Tagore but rather is a compilation of various speeches by him. Nevertheless, his diction is classic.

This was my first reading of Tagore, and this completely justified to me why this legend is a Literature Nobel Laureate.

Abstruse style of writing.
Most of the point I found not relevant in today's world. Book is not for someone who wants to understand what nationalism is, it's nuances, how it affects nation etc.
To be honest it's just a long verbiage.
You can read it in one sitting so no harm in buying it if u want to check for yourself.
Book was in excellent condition when received.

The Blue Umbrella is a novella by Ruskin Bond, wherein he weaves a beautiful story of an ordinary village girl Binya and her love for the blue umbrella. Binya traded this beautiful blue umbrella for her only possession, a leopard claw necklace. So, this story is basically about the struggles of Binya to keep the umbrella safe from everyone and how she ended up giving it to someone out of a sudden realisation.

This story conveys multiple emotions, like the happiness for small things, materialistic joys, kindness and jealousy over the beautiful umbrella and it's ends with a beautiful message, that there is more joy in giving, then owning something.‚ù§Ô∏è

A pretty little umbrella which is blue in color brings unbound happiness in Binya‚Äôs life. She carries it everywhere with so much love and affection. There is this old shopkeeper Ram Bharosa who is eyeing this prized possession of the young girl of Garhwal. He tries to have his way and get the umbrella under his paws. Would he be successful?

A simple and short story of kindness and humanity is The Blue Umbrella. In this classic novella, Ruskin paints a vivid image of Garhwal where the story is set. Binya exchanges her leopard‚Äôs claw pendant for the blue silk umbrella. And when she comes across the frenzied and despairing state of Ram Bharosa, she does the unimaginable. As she says that an umbrella is not everything. This displays her sensibility and humility. This act of hers opens the heart of the old shopkeeper and positivity flows in. In short, there is a mix of heroism and redemption in this sweet story which is an ideal read for kids but could be equally enjoyed by the adults.

\n I am new to English language books. So, just want to try out some random books to start my journey in English literature. Found it randomly in Amazon with such a less price. At first I was little shocked to see how tiny and short book it is. But as I start reading it, oh my my...such a beautiful story of a hillside girl. There is nothing extraordinary but it's all about those minute details that the writer protraied with so much affection and in such delightful way. For all those story lovers and who want to start their English literature journey this is a must book written in so simple language that you don't need to look up to dictionary everytime.\n

column4: A ravishing story, which IMO, should be in school books
column5:
This novella is about a mountain girl, Binya, from Garhwal who lives with her mother and brother, Bijju and her cows, Neelu & Gori.

The story narrates the characters around her life and how she fell in love with a blue umbrella and gives away her lucky charm for it and yet gives away the umbrella only to see Ram Bharosa happy.

Binya's story beautifully portrays how life is much more than attachment to materials and that "What goes around comes around" in a positive way.

\n It's very inspiring story. The way Ruskin Bond has narrated the story is incredible. He takes me a tour to himalayas through his narration. From this book i have understood that Life is not about getting something from anyone it is about giving to others to make them to feel happy üòä.\n

column4: "The Blue Umbrella" takes the readers on an amazing ride through mother nature and human emotions.
column5:
"The Umbrella was like a flower, a great blue flower that had sprung up on the dry brown hillside."

Weaved in Ruskin Bond's signature style, "The Blue Umbrella" is a short humorous read that captures the simple life in a hill village where ordinary characters become heroic and others find opportunities to redeem themselves.

Binya falls in love with the blue umbrella as soon as she sets her eyes on it. She wants it so much that she readily exchanges her lucky leopard's claw pendant for it. She carries the umbrella wherever she goes and always keeps it open. No one in the village has ever seen or possessed such a beautiful umbrella. They envy her for her precious possession. The most envious of them is Ram Bharosa, the shopkeeper who tries various means to own the blue umbrella. But beauty always comes with a price, doesn't it?

Ruskin Bond have a way of carrying his readers away to a distant land of possibilities. Be it his short stories, novels or novellas, he never falls short of spinning tales that touch the heart. "The Blue Umbrella" is one of those stories that takes the readers on an amazing ride through mother nature and human emotions.

The simple story of a village girl in love with a beautiful blue umbrella is powerful enough to teach us a lot in a short span. The ending brings to us a great lesson that we often fail to realize in life. Once again Ruskin Bond stikes gold with his magnificent story that teaches us the value of love, emotion, relationships and life itself. The beauty in simplicity that the book projects is sure to leave one wondering for a long time.

Author : Ruskin Bond
Publisher: Rupa
'The umbrella was like a flower, a great blue flower that had sprung up on the dry brown hillside.'
Our protagonist of the story is Binyadevi or Binya as she is called by everyone from her village. She lives a simple life with her mother & elder brother Vijay or Bijju. One fine day she acquires a beautiful bright blue umbrella from some picnickers who came at the hills of Garhwal in exchange of her lucky leopard‚Äôs claw necklace. The story beautifully revolves around how she gets attached to the umbrella while a shopkeeper named Ram Bharosa eyed on it & plans to acquire it somehow.
The Blue Umbrella by Ruskin Bond is a children‚Äôs book. The story is short and simple but elegantly touches the core aspect of humanity - kindness. Through Binya Ruskin instils a sense of kindness among children. A morning all Ruskin Bond books, The Blue Umbrella has, so far, gathered immense applaud from readers and critics alike. This is a short novel, but the kind of moral lessons it teaches to us are simply overwhelming.

This is a story of Binya, a poor little girl living with her mother and an elder brother, Bijju, in a small hilly village of Garhwal. One day while herding her two cows back home, she stumbles upon some city people enjoying the picnic in the valley. She is enthralled to see them well-groomed and rich. She craves to be one like them and among many other things of their, a blue frilly umbrella catches her attention. She begins craving for it. On the other hand, the city people get attracted by her innocent beauty and the pendant in her neck. The pendant consists of leopard‚Äôs claw ‚Äì which is considered a mascot widely in the hills. Binya trades her pendant off with the blue umbrella.

column4: This is a sweet and a humble that will fill you with happiness and nostalgia.
column5:
GRANDMA'S BAG of STORIES by SUDHA MURTY üòäüòä

What is your fav Children's Book??

This book by Sudha Murty is like that warm sun that you wanna feel on a cold winter morning. It will boost your soul and spirits, fill your heart with longing and happiness & will take you back to the time when life was simpler and fun.

It is a collection of 22 short stories told by Ajji to her grandchildren Raghu, Meenu,Anand, Krishna and their neighbourhood friends. The grandchildren come to their grandparents place during their summer vacations. Their grandparents house is away from the hustle-bustle of the city life; surrounded by greenery and open field. The children however are most excited about the stories that Ajji is going to tell them during their stay with her.

The stories told by the grandmother are short & sweet moral stories. These stories deal on wide variety of topics such as importance of:
üìç hard work &honesty
üìçbeing down to earth, being helpful & humble & content & loyal
üìçhaving presence of mind
üìçloving people unconditionally
All the stories will fill you up with hope and that feeling of content that you used to feel if your grandparents also told you stories.

The narration is very effective as you will be able to retain the stories for a long time. The tone is full of warmth. The book is woven in a way to make you feel nostalgic.The book brought back strong memories of my childhood when my brother & me used to travel to my native place with our parents to meet our grandparents during summer & winter breaks. Those memories were overwhelming. The smile that used to break on my Amma's & Dadaji's face are images that I would cherish for my lifetime. It's a shame that I lost them so early.

 This was my first Sudha Murty book & I am so glad that I picked up her book. It brought me out of my reading slump of 2 long months. It's a very sweet & a humble book. Do give it a read. You will not at all be disappointed.

How to Stop Worrying and Start Living is a self-help book by Dale Carnegie.
 It was first printed in Great Britain in 1948 by Richard Clay (The Chaucer Press), Ltd., Bungay Suffolk (S.B.N. 437 95083 2).
It is currently published as a Mass Market Paperback of 352 pages by Pocket (Revised edition: September 15, 1990)
Carnegie says in the preface to How to Stop Worrying and Start Living that he wrote it because he "was one of the unhappiest lads in New York". He said that he made himself sick with worry because he hated his position in life, which he attributes to wanting to figure out how to stop worrying.

The book's goal is to lead the reader to a more enjoyable and fulfilling life, helping them to become more aware of, not only themselves, but others around them.
 Carnegie tries to address the everyday nuances of living, in order to get the reader to focus on the more important aspects of life.
It is now a world-famous, self-help book amongst many people

How to Break the Worry Habit Before It Breaks You Edit
Keep busy
Don't fuss about trifles
Use the law of averages to outlaw your worries
Cooperate with the Inevitable
Decide just how much anxiety a thing may be worth and refuse to give it more
Don't worry about the past

column4: Simple & Light Reading. May Disappoint - Dependent on Reader's Expectation.
column5:
The book does a decent job of relating the concept of Ikigai to modern day psychology (with Frankl's Logotherapy from Man's Search for Meaning among others) and a few scientific references in a simple manner. It talks about how purpose plays an important role in a man's life and the different ways in which it manifests itself. It also tackles some ways to 'find your flow' and ensure that what you do receives 100% of your attention and that you enjoy whatever you are creating.

The book also discusses certain other Japanese concepts like takumi (specialized workers) and moai (connections with community or friend-circle). The brief discussions have the benefit of being to the point and simple but also pose the risk of trivializing them into regular self-help advice. The book also delves into Japanese perspectives on living life and persevering without getting caught up in artificially-created urgency. But again, maybe the authors wished for the readers to research more or meditate more on the content given the concise treatment of the same.

The chapters on diet and exercises have more details and thus, may be more useful. Certain foods are dealt with in greater detail as is the concept of 'hara hachi bu' wherein one eats only 80% of what would actually assuage his hunger. The chapter on exercises includes illustrations and steps. While they may suffice for some of the purposes mentioned in the book - the philosophy behind them, progressive increments and other essential details are missing or insufficient.

I was interested in the concept of Ikigai and wanted to read more about it. Despite being well-written and presenting modern applications, the book did not fulfill my requirements at all. Some of the condensed content made me think that the extended research, including on-site interviews, done by the authors for writing this book was clearly lost in translation or presentation in certain parts.

The hardcover is pretty and soothing with its matte texture. Inner pages are smooth and heavy with a cream tinge. The font size is good. The spine as well as pages hold up well. Overall, the book is quite light and sturdy. Bought it for INR 460 against MRP of INR 499.
\n Just read a back of book and its enough dont waste like meüò¢\n

Ikigai
The Japanese Secret to a Long and Happy Life
By Hector Garcia and Francesc Miralles

I will be confessing by saying that i bought this book just because of its attractive cover, such a soothing color combination which itself calmed me.

This book is all about finding your passion in life, your ‚Äúikigai‚Äù which will help you to live a happy, content, active and long life. It talks about art of staying young while growing old, about relaxing, about not running behind materialistic things, how to improve your performance in daily routine and to stay focused.

One of the best lesson which I liked was how to be more anti fragile. It talked about creating more options, by devoting time in your passion, taking small risks for increasing your experience and to get rid of the things which makes us more fragile.

Before reading this book I felt that there would be some manoeuvre to follow for finding your ikigai, but there is just overview of many therapies which left me little unsatisfied and disappointed. There were few things like proverbs, quotes and traditions from centritains which I found were not really required. There is no rocket science written in this book but some of the facts are eye opening.

P. S . And seriously I wish I could learn sun salutation and other exercise by reading.

Overall I will say it‚Äôs a easy, simple read for beginners for setting up small goals.

Only staying active will make you want to live a hundred years.
‚Äî‚Äî-Japanese proverb

Book starts with this proverb and this literally summarises the book.

column4: If you want a long, fulfilling life, get this book.
column5:
Ikigai - Book review

A pure GEM. Short (1 hour to finish), massively impactful & UPLIFTING.

Ikigai is a Japanese concept, which means ‚Äúthe happiness of always being busy". It explains the extraordinary longevity of the Japanese, especially on the island of Okinawa, where

there are 24.55 people over the age of 100 for every 100,000 inhabitants!

What I LOVED about the book is a reiteration of FACTS that we all know. Best ones:

- Never RETIRE. (If you have recently retired parents who are grumpy & throw tantrums, give them this book)

- Stop eating JUST when you are about to get full. ‚ÄúHara hachi bu" means something like ‚ÄúFill your belly to 80 percent.‚Äù

- SLEEEEEP!!! Top models sleep a lot!

- How to handle thoughts, emotions, BOREDOM. Vietnamese monk Thich Nhat Hanh, who would say, ‚ÄúHello, solitude. How are you today? Come, sit with me, and I will care for you.‚Äù

- A list of different Japanese meditations & practices.

- The Pomodoro Technique to FOCUS : Get yourself a kitchen timer & commit to working on a single task as long as it‚Äôs running.

If you want a long, fulfilling life, get this book.

column4: The Best Things In Life Are Simple !
column5:
To be completely honest I bought this book just because of its cover. I mean just take a moment and observe it, the perfect shade of blue with white flowers. Simplicity at its best. This book has some sort of vibe, I still remember how I smiled when I opened the amazon parcel and found this bundle of positivity and happiness. The sheer pleasure of caressing its pages which is very different as compared to the regular pages of other novels, it gives you immense relief Idk how and why, but it does. Coming to the main content, the book starts by telling the meaning of Ikigai i.e.,purpose of your life, reason to get out of your bed every morning happily and how finding your Ikigai will lead to a long and happy life. The importance of society and a friendly neighbourhood is well put.The interviews of the Japanese Centenarians explains why they are the longest living human beings on this planet, they do the simple activities like gardening also with full enthusiasm, they aren‚Äôt spending their retirement resting on an arm chair instead they attend Karaoke nights, indulge in group activities, sell their produce in vegetable market and believe in eating simple and exercising.They live in present and enjoy every moment happily. Because being aware of the impermanence of things does not have to make us sad; it should help us love the present and those who surround us.'
ü¶ã
Our Ikigai is different for all of us but one thing we have in common is that we are all searching for meaning. There is no perfect strategy of connecting with our ikigai. But what we learned from the Okinawans is that we should not worry too much about finding it. Like the author said ‚ÄúLife is not a problem to be solved. Just remember to have something that keeps you busy doing what you love while being surrounded by the people who love you‚Äù. The simplest things are often the most beautiful, and this book is the perfect example of this statement. ' Eat right, exercise, and do what makes you happy'...by following this motto, we can definitely find our 'ikagai', our reason to live.

column4: Redesign your lifestyle for longevity and happiness
column5:
We all want to lead a long and healthy life. Don‚Äôt we? Ikigai has all the elements to decode it.
 Ikigai is a Japanese word, translates to ‚Äú the happiness of always being busy or engaged‚Äù. The people of Okinawa live a simple outdoor life, drink green tea, and eat a healthy diet served in a special bowl that limits to their eating. The book explains that every being has an Ikigai, a journey of self-discovery and it‚Äôs worth the search. Ikigai draws attention to the lifestyle of Japanese people showcasing how they lead an optimal healthy life, filled with happiness, and longevity. The main focus is on diet, daily activities and a sense of joy. It also includes wisdom from supercentenarians(above the age of 110) from all over the world.Every individual's Ikigai is different but the search is common. Still searching for you Ikigai, no worries, smile, take a long breath and find one. I‚Äôm all praises for this book and cannot stop gushing about it. Grab it today.

column4: Ikigai: The Japanese secret to a long and happy life üíì
column5: \n The people of Japan believe that everyone has an ikigai ‚Äì a reason to jump out of bed each morning. And according to the residents of the Japanese island of Okinawa ‚Äì the world‚Äôs longest-living people ‚Äì finding it is the key to a longer and more fulfilled life. Inspiring and comforting, this book will give you the life-changing tools to uncover your personal ikigai. It will show you how to leave urgency behind, find your purpose, nurture friendships and throw yourself into your passions.\n

\n Although, this book goes on about the same thing in depth throughout, it is still an important message that it is trying to convey. This is a life changing concept to live by and I realised that I found my ikigai as I got the book (such coincidence!) and this is something I am glad I did not miss at this point of my life <3\n

\n Ikigai is for all age. I insist even school kids be encouraged to read this life changer. It's fairly simple and easier than the rest of the self help books I have read. It's crisp length makes it read twice. Yes, I read it twice. Re-read soon after I finished the first time. To the cons, somewhere I felt there's a gap in explaining what an Ikigai is in the first few chapters. Could have been put out in a much more clear definition for simplicity's sake. But yet the book certainly is a clear torch bearing guide for a happy, healthy and meaningful life. You can relate the teachings to your life as you read. Truly, Ikigai helps!\n

I read so many good reviews on this book that I decided to buy it. I am a fan of fiction, hence, it doesn't fit my favourite genre but it's a good, light read that reflects on our lifestyle and how it is different, dismally different from the cenetenarians. The book has some interesting facts and will make you think where you are going wrong.
‚ú®If you decide to shift to a healthy and happy lifestyle and need some inspiration, this is the book for ya.‚ú®

How to Stop Worrying and Start Living is a self-help book by Dale Carnegie.
 It was first printed in Great Britain in 1948 by Richard Clay (The Chaucer Press), Ltd., Bungay Suffolk (S.B.N. 437 95083 2).
It is currently published as a Mass Market Paperback of 352 pages by Pocket (Revised edition: September 15, 1990)
Carnegie says in the preface to How to Stop Worrying and Start Living that he wrote it because he "was one of the unhappiest lads in New York". He said that he made himself sick with worry because he hated his position in life, which he attributes to wanting to figure out how to stop worrying.

The book's goal is to lead the reader to a more enjoyable and fulfilling life, helping them to become more aware of, not only themselves, but others around them.
 Carnegie tries to address the everyday nuances of living, in order to get the reader to focus on the more important aspects of life.
It is now a world-famous, self-help book amongst many people

How to Break the Worry Habit Before It Breaks You Edit
Keep busy
Don't fuss about trifles
Use the law of averages to outlaw your worries
Cooperate with the Inevitable
Decide just how much anxiety a thing may be worth and refuse to give it more
Don't worry about the past

column4: A book full of life. A must read!
column5:
This novel got me me into thinking, if it was possible for a child of unfavourable disposition and health to get any better and live life so willingly in a forthright manner, I would plant a thousand Secret Gardens in every corner of the world. There would be no sickness, or suffering ever!

But on a second note I think maybe there really are a thousand Secret Gardens already and only because it must be a secret, no one can tell. All we need is to believe in 'magic' to uncover them and make them burst forth with energy and spirit that it will become so hard not to live.

This book makes me believe there is magic, even as an adult - not of fairylands or elves but of a kind which can be made quite possible in today's world. There's no better way to end this decade. Cheers Frances H. Brunett!

The Secret Garden is a children's novel by Frances Hodgson Burnett first published as a book in 1911, after a version was published as an American magazine serial beginning in 1910. In the spirit of A Little Princess, this story recognises the characteristics we must prize most as human beings. The Secret Garden is a "lovely" story in every sense of the word. Primarily, it's about three kids: Mistress Mary, Dickon, and Master Colin--and how just thinking a little differently can change a person completely. column5:
I've read the reviews however i dared to buy this set.

However i could guarantee you now that this publication is either not having any quality control mechanism or they are duping people in name of cheap combo offers.

As an avid reader i can say that a book must be complete and print quality must not be inconsistent.

This book set has surprisingly few grammatical and spelling errors, that i noticed while turning pages and also worst page color consistency.

I'd like to ask every new buyer to avoid this combo, because you only would end up buying cheap crap thats either torn, misprint, blank pages, incomplete page, missing page.

I've never lashed at any product review, but this seems to be a real bad product that no one is willing to improve quality be it Seller or Amazon (by banning such duping product or selles)

Note: Above said issue was true as on 29th April 2021. Only 1 book have severe issues, rest 3 have minor mistakes and page color defects.

column4: Both the publisher & the seller pathetic
column5:
I was looking for the best hardcover copy of this international best seller to gift someone.
For such a celebrated book the publisher took liberty to (a) use poor quality paper, (b) provide extremely poor quality printing of the pictures and (c) omit specifying price anywhere on the book.
And the seller (a) didn‚Äôt even bother to check before shipping a hardcover book for which the binding has come off and (b) doesn‚Äôt allow you to return and get refund (they allow only replacement, which I requested and got). Incidentally, there‚Äôs a much better quality product from Yogada Satsanga Society of India available in amazon at 1/4 the price. I do have a hardcover copy from them and it‚Äôs much better. And you should have multiple sellers for that at Amazon.

column4: Teaches you to seek your own happiness
column5:
What to expect?
Expect a book that is a detailed read, one that is bound to take you days to read, and weeks or months to fully implement the lessons that it has to teach.

Who can read?
The book is written in a language that can be easily understood by a beginner level reader.

What is the book all about?
‚ÄúThink Like a Monk‚Äù is a book that helps us live a more peaceful and purposeful life; one that is full of gratitude and brimming with positivity. No, the book doesn‚Äôt promise us overnight miracles, but what it does promise is a sense of calmness, a change of attitude, more love, more positivity, and better clarity of who we are.

How good is the writing style?
The book reads like a conversation, and there is an instant connection that the reader feels with the author. Given the subject, the book doesn‚Äôt feel preachy at all.

Is the book interesting to read?
Yes. Take your time, read it slowly, perhaps a chapter a day, and you will definitely find the book interesting and enriching.

In the end
In the end, ‚ÄúThink Like a Monk‚Äù is a book that offers both conventional as well as unconventional wisdom in an attempt to make our lives better, happier, more peaceful, and purposeful.

Pick the book if
You love reading self-help.
You are looking for books that inculcate a spiritual mindset.
You want to be a better, happier, and more positive version of yourself.

Skip the book if
You are looking for a short read.
You are looking for a read that aims to better you in the professional sphere.
You have previously read many other books about happiness, wellbeing, peace, purpose, and spirituality.

column4: Breath is the only element which comes when we are born and stay with us till we die.
column5:
'People Come into your life a reason, a season or a lifetime.'
.
Book Name- Think Like a Monk
Author- Jay Shetty
.
The book is teaching us how we are always busy in this world where there is nothing ours. One of the sayings I read which were that 'A monk went to a king's palace and asked him if he could stay in his hotel. The king in anger shouted it's not a hotel; it's my palace. The monk in a calm voice asks that before you whose place was this? the king told that it was his father palace. The monk asked, and before him? The king with surprised doesn't know why he is asking all this answered that before him, it was his grandfather palace. The monk replied with a simple sigh that, see everyone came and stayed here but left one day and where people come and stay and then leave we called it a Hotel.' This was a simple story but gives the best seek in this world that nothing in this world is yours. Yesterday it was of someone, Today it is yours, but tomorrow it will be someone else. So never depend on the materialistic thing in life.
Best book. It is telling how to calm in a difficult situation and how to stand in difficult climatic conditions of life.

Which is that Self-Help book that inspired you to read more such books??
'Think Like A Monk' by Jay Shetty is that book for me. This book became a part of my morning routine .

I don't pick up self-help or similar books unless and until someone strongly recommends that to me but i pre-ordered this book . It's bcoz i've been following him for many years and i am also an avid listener of his podcast ' ON PURPOSE' and that made me trust him with his debut book.

And if you also like podcasts then i strongly recommend the audiobook version of this book. Trust me! It's quite impactful when he reads out the book to you.

This s not a book which will tell you how to become successful or how to make more money. You could do all those by yourself if you have a right mind for that and that is what is the highlight of this book i.e 'Peace, Purpose and Mindfulness' and it is rightly the 1st step for everything and in today's world this is 100% relevant.

'Try this' exercises in between the chapters were the best part. He also mentions breath work , visualisation techniques, and chants that are helpful for meditation.

Writing is lucid and i recommend this book to everyone.!!!! Do give it a try...i am sure u'll luv it...

column4: A phenomenal, revolutionary life changing book
column5:
As Jay Shetty mentioned in his book- Every time we do anything or dwell further into something that we like- we need to question ourselves ( our presence of mind and heart) : "What did I like about that?" Do I want to read about it, learn about it, spend my time doing it"
Am I here just for the outcome or I want to learn through the process of what it has in store to offer me?

As I further questioned myself with all these questions, I realized every word mentioned in the book was helping me become more self-aware of myself. It wasn't something that I was hearing for the first time but it was definitely something that my mind, body and soul was trying to tell me all this time but there was too much dust within my clogged thoughts and that's exactly what it helped me with- cleanse. This book has so magnificently captured and articulated emotions of a human mind, people's fear and how they overcome it and described it with examples that any person could relate to in his personal life. Every small details has been explained with verses from Bhagavad Gita and quotes said by famous personalities with examples. This book has not only asks you to read but it gives you activities to perform which help you in becoming more aware of your positives and negatives. Jay's words are so realistic and accomplishable that you'll feel driven to greet each day with discipline and motivation along with guidance that helps everyone achieve their destined journey. This book will successfully manage to break free from the perspective of the outside world and helps in conditioning the strong character in our own lives. I really want people to read this book as it helped me a lot in changing my mindset about my workplace and guided me to achieve my true dharma. Moreover, I truly believe this is just the beginning of the best services and dharma that the author is giving out to the world. And, I am definitely here for the learning process. The outcome will automatically come to us when we start growing exponentially as better individuals in our lives.
\n This is a much awaited book in my list. I have been listening to him from last 2 years around and he really motivates his listeners. Thank you Jay\n

column4: No complexities, he made wisdom really made simple and relatable
column5:
I personally started following Jay in his initial days, I had just lost my father and was going through a really hard time provided that I had clinical depression back then. I remember scrolling down the Facebook feed and finding his page as a suggestion was literally a blessing.
Fast forwarding to now, in his book, her has covered three major aspects
LET GO, GROW AND GIVE
THE FIRST TWO ASPECTS INCLUDE
1. Identification of one's own self without the influence of outer noice
2. Overcoming fear and negativity through easy sets of daily exercises
3. Setting the right intention with a calm and composed mind so that one is able to find his purpose and commits to it
THEN COMES THE LAST ONE (GIVE)
This aspect throws light on the power of giving, gratitude and service.
I love the quote he has mentioned, stated as "APPRECIATE EVERYTHING, EVEN THE ORDINARY, ESPECIALLY THE ORDINARY"
JAY has always been an inspiration to youth, I'm 18 and I know such a depth of relationships and self compassion just because of the wisdom this book contains. I am healing my wounds, my relationship with people around me, this book with change your perspective and will move you in ways nothing can.
 PS :- I've rated it four stars because it's his book where he has compiled years of wisdom in one frame, but I personally feel he has so much more depth that is yet to spread.

column4: Mental booster to fight any disease in your mind !!
column5:
Don‚Äôt know exactly how to write the review for a book ,because this is the first time in my life I‚Äôm writing a review for the book . Hope I start implementing the main principle of the book right from here -how monk think at this moment ??(to write a review for the book now ). Myself being a doctor , leading a relatively more stressful phase at this Covid pandemic time , mainly due to fear of acquiring Covid disease to myself , my family members, friends , and others in the society , I am very glad to have read this book. Apart from the normal times, these Covid times have put more of stress , burden , agony and fear to all health care workers in various aspects of their life and draining them physically and mentally. There are also cases reported in healthy people who with the fear of getting covid positive or who are tested positive succumbed to death just due to their mental agony and fear of Covid . So apart from the treatment by medications and vaccines , it requires lot of mental Courage & emotional support to fight and overcome such diseases . So this book in particular is must a read for everyone , to gain mental stability and positivity especially in these pandemic situations. Apart from the social distance precautions, mask wear, Diet , personal hygiene and immune booster supplementation , this book can work as a mental booster to everyone of us .

The author has beautifully divided the book into three parts - Let Go, Grow and Give , with each of the part having various chapters described under. Right from the first page , the author takes through to a wonderful ride to an enlightened atmosphere driven by a positive energy vehicle . There are various highlighted phrases , quotes and sayings described throughout the book and can be read many a times to develop positive Vibes.There is lot of focus on personality Development , positive emotions and habits described in the book which are motivating . There are beautiful Small Stories described in the book which are given as examples to apply to ourselves .There are real life incidents of the authors lifestyle at the ashram with the monks which makes us get connected and also adding liveliness to the book . The core of the book mainly deals with the different kinds of meditations to train our mind for peace and finding purpose everyday. There‚Äôs lot to be experienced internally rather than externally. Hence I am unable to put my book experience in the words .
Apart from name, fame , money , luxuries and etc , there‚Äôs lot to be dealt internally which gives more happiness to us such as by our kindness , gratitude and service which are beautifully explained in the book . The main thing which I learnt the most in the book is to find happiness internally and being grateful for what we have in our life .

I would recommend this book to my friends , family members and also people who are mentally sick , so they would go through this wonderful journey of positive energy . Also in this pandemic situation, where home isolation is the main treatment for many of us , this book is a must read to improve our mental , physical and emotional stability .
Words wouldn‚Äôt suffice to express my gratitude or thanks to the author Jayshetty and his team for delivering such a masterpiece book to the world and enhancing many lives . Words are actually short for me to describe the experience I had while reading the book . May you write many more books like these and transform as many as Possible to the positive energy. Thank you so much Sir !! -Dr.Sushruth Gowtham

The book has come to me at a time that I needed it the most. I have an injured foot and as I started reading the book it became clear to me that it is time for me to heal from inside . I bought the audible and the book. I decided to read the book along with Jay‚Äôs voice - it has been a profound experience of transformation!
The book is clear and it shows you ‚Äúhow to do‚Äù and it almost is like a daily guidance that you could access any page and find the best approach and perspective filled with direction and love . It is a great gift for all your loved ones, including children- as these are things we need to train our little amazing humans on. @jayshetty the intention to serve for greater good for all has left a profound impact on me!
My favourite line from the book is in the conclusion ‚ÄúYou have to go your way, Take life with you‚Äù
Everyone, absorb Think Like a Monk - many times over!

column4: The most beautiful book I have ever read.
column5:
The book says, ‚ÄòThe Classic tribute to hope from Holocaust‚Äô. And Sir Frankl was a ‚ÄúHolocaust survivor".

This book has two parts:
1.Experiences in a Concentration Camp.
2.Logotherapy in a Nutshell

The second part is so impactful and unique that you will re-read this book. The first part mainly is the autobiographical account of Sir, Frankl and the best part is both parts mutually support their credibility.
The way he has poured all the pain in this book is not so easy and that too after experiencing it, I was literally shocked because firstly, I was unaware of the term ‚ÄúHolocaust‚Äù, maybe I have read before somewhere in History but I was unaware while reading and Secondly, I had never come across something like this.

He has talked about everything related to life in this book and you know what the best part is even after so much pain, I felt sad but I wasn‚Äôt demotivated, I could relate it and with each page-turning, what I found was ‚ÄòI am into the book‚Äô, suffering all this but I wasn‚Äôt tackling all the worst situation in my life as he did.
Suddenly I started understanding that what life is? what suffering is? and what surviving is? and where am I lacking?

So, in another way, I discovered the answer to three most important questions which I wanted to be answered since maturity.

I came across a new word ‚ÄúLogotherapy‚Äù and I loved that section so much that I will re-read this book.
In one line, I learned a lot from this book, which I can further practice to live a peaceful and beautiful life ahead. And this what makes this book worth reading.

column4: Must Read for all of us
column5:
This book is a small book divided into 2 parts
You need to understand that‚Äôs it‚Äôs not a story only.
The first part recounts of various experiences of Dr. Frankl as a prisoner in Nazi Concentration Camps, he does not go too much into the details but gives us a fair idea of suffering which the inmates went through. He also keep giving advice after or during the recital of these experiences.
The second part is quite complicated. In fact students of psychology and psychiatric will find it easy to understand. It‚Äôs important to read it and may be it will take you some time to understand. But some of the concepts are very important to be understood by the millennials in 21st century.
I would recommend that you read it twice without anyone disturbing you and relate it to your real life incidents. We might not have been in concentration camps but we all have been in situations when we have become hopeless and almost ready to give up.

Font size of the paperback edition for India is really small. It should have been bigger

I Must Say That The Book Is An Optimistic Approach For Searching The Real Meaning Of Life ..

But While Reading The Book, I Found That Mr. Frankl Promoted His Research On Logotherapy Too, So, I Might Be Wrong But The Book Is A Promoting Piece For Logotherapy.

And Overall .
The First Chapter consists A Lot Of Stories Of The Holocaust That Will Make You Think Over The World War II.

The Second Chapter is A MasterPiece Work That Will Leave A Lasting Impression On Your Personality.

And Lastly Only One Word
‚úåÔ∏è MasterPiece ‚úåÔ∏è
Because Of The Second Chapter ‚ù§Ô∏è

column4: Choose any seller that's not "Sasta books"
column5:
Avoid the seller "Sasta books" like the plague. They were the default.

Inconsistent page layout. Lines of text not parallel to the page end. Grease smudges on the inside of the cover. Cover was creased. A random search in the local junkyard would fetch me a book in better condition than the one I've been sold.

I've placed a return and refund request.

If you read but one book this year, "Man's search for meaning" should be the one .

Frankl question the existence of human beings .First he let us go in dispear then give his hands to see the brighter picture (perspective should be the word) of the world.
He emphasized the philosophy of Nietzsche by quoting "he who has a why to live for can be almost any more".He stated if suffering is inevitable then you must bear with it,but if you can avoid it , avoid it at any cost.

This book helped me a lot during this lockdown.Hope it'll not disappoint you as well.

\n As always book was deliverd in two days .However somewhat dissapointed by the quality of the book.It was not par with standard amazon book.Must be duplicate copy.Book size is small.And find book font somewhat little.Now coming to the book, It is novel written by Viktor E. Frankl telling his experiences in the concentration camps run during WW2 in Nazi Germany.This book gives hope to everyone in worst situation when there is no light in the end of tunnel.It also talks about logotherapy.First part of the book is very easy to understand but later part of the book contains philosophical terms and medical treatment to treat the mentally ill persons.It is a motivational book who are struggling in the lives. In a nutshell this is not a light reading but would suggest only if you are are moderate or heavy reader.\n

The story is about a boy from Andalsuia and his adventures through African desert to find treasure in Pyramids of Egypt. One can easily relate with the story because we all have our own goals and this book will teach you that no matter how many obstacles come in your way you should never give up

As per the quality of book goes, It's not that great, Pages are low quality. But the texts are readable without getting strain in your eyes. So I can say the quality of book is okay

I'm giving 4 star because of the low quality of the book.
I hope this review will help you in your buying decision.

This book is not for you if you are looking for a way to escape reality by immersing into a juicy plot during the week end. This book is about you, me and anyone and everyone .It is about our life, our troubles and tribulations, our goals and the purpose of our existence. To determine our goal ( or Personal Legend as Coelho terms) and to pursue and achieve it is not difficult if we are focused because in the words of Coelho,"..... when you want something, all the universe conspires in helping you to achieve it."

The story is that of a shepard boy named, Santiago ,from Andulasia. The boy embarks upon a journey in search of a treasure that he had dreamt of. Each one of us are, infact, Santiago, unable to realise when and where we spilt 'the spoon of oil '. As you go through the book you learn that all is not lost and there is hope.

Narrated in a simple lucid manner,the story is interspersed with metaphors ,fables and allegories. Compelling, interesting and full of hope and positivity, The Alchemist is a bedrock of inspiration that instills a strong sense of faith in yourself.

Such is the power of this book that you will want to read it again and again. Paulo Coelho has an uncanny knack to soothe your soul and boost your morale. This book, in my opinion, should be read by everyone, young and old, atleast once .

\n The Alchemist by Paulo Coelho is the book which I always go back to. I have a different take away whenever I read it and it has helped me to become wiser with time. Basically it is a fable about following your dreams and is a story of a shepherd named Santiago who dares to follow his dream. He faces obstacles, failures and hardship throughout but he decides to hold on to his dream.\n

column4: The lessons are good but the story sucks
column5:
The philosophy was good ,the hurdles which everybody encounter in the way of pursuing their own dream is to test them which is a fact.
This book made me disappointed as I expected more from it because of the fame it has.
 The story sucks but the lessons are to be learned from it which are
-> follow your heart, heed the voice of it.
-> everything in life has it's price
-> Life is the moment we are living now
-> It's not what enter's men's mouths that's evil, it's what comes out of their mouths that is.
-> No project is completed until it's objective has been achieved.
This are the some of the lessons which everyone should learn, although I don't believe in conspiring of whole world for your dream it's just the thought of whole universe having your back will make your strength and you just tends to push yourself towards your goal.

\n Don‚Äôt fall for it. Just a fancy book and flattering cover. The thousand of five star ratings is misleading. An extremely over- rated book. Do not hope anything to learn or gain something from this book instead, use your time and money on a different book.\n

column4: Such a magical book that's why strongly recommend to every classic lover (reader) !!
column5:
" Reading the Alchemist was like getting up at dawn and seeing the sun rise while the rest of the world still slept." I've read all type of books but 'The Alchemist' is so different in every aspects.
üîñ
*Book Review*
~
The Alchemist- By Paulo Coelho.
üîñ
The cover of the book is simple,decent and focusing at the main plot of the story. The book is a light read of approx 160 pages where the author impeccably written the story with very impressive narration, plot and characters. This great book have changed my way of thinking about goals and destiny, completely.
üîñ
"Every man kills the thing he loves."
~
The story revolves around a young boy, a shepherd who wants to fulfill his dream to see the great pyramids and find the treasure, that he had seen in his dream. So he went to reach his destiny and in doing so, he met different new souls who helped him to complete his journey to see the pyramids and the treasure.
üîñ
"Your eyes show the strength of your soul."
~
He met with a desert girl, Fatima and both fell in love with each other. Later he met with main character of the story, an Alchemist who educated him about the alchemy and helped to achieve his dream. During the journey, the boy learnt many lessons of the desert.
üîñ
The author have so brilliantly written this book with an amazing plots and lessons that i have finished it in less than a day. I strongly recommend this magical piece to every reader who wants to pick their next read (classic).
I'm sure after reading this book you will come to know that "There is only one thing that makes a dream impossible to achieve: the fear of failure."
üîñ
My ratings- 5/5 ‚≠ê

column4: It comes under "Books-You-must-read-before-you-Die" List. Please Go for it.
column5:
I must say this book is not only a book, it's a whole new world out there for you to discover and learn. It will change your life for sure and the perspective of you towards life. Paulo Coelho is so far my favourite Author & I loved the way he wrote about the shepherd boy, his dreams, his love for a new girl & his achievements in the end.
To be very honest, The whole conversation between The Alchemist & The Shepherd Boy is what I found the most interesting. Before reading this book, I really didn't believe in Destiny, fate or similar kind of concepts. But this book changed the whole idea of these things & now I clearly believe in Destiny!

The story revolves around a Spanish shepherd named Santiago who yearns to travel the world. He has a repetitive dream about a hidden treasure in the Egyptian pyramids. An old gypsy and a mysterious old man strengthens his beliefs about the treasure. This book is about his journey from Andalusia to Egypt, a journey where he discovers himself. Do read to know if Santiago will be able to face all obstacles and find the treasure and what the treasure was?‚Å£
‚Å£
Its a simple yet powerful book. It‚Äôs a book about a dreamer that chases his dream with a thriving passion. It emphasises and teaches one about faith, optimism, destiny, following dreams and love.‚Å£
The Alchemist by Paulo Coelho is a must-read for avid readers. ‚Å£

column4: The Alchemist focuses on "dreams are made to be followed".
column5:
Reading ‚ÄúThe Alchemist‚Äù feels less like reading a book and more like sitting around a fire in the desert listening to an ancient story being passed down through oral tradition. Despite its meaningful content, ‚ÄúThe Alchemist‚Äù is a very quick and easy read.

Through Santiago‚Äôs journey to treasure and love and travel, Coelho encourages readers to not only discover their own dreams for their lives, but also to never give up pursuing them.

It also offers a simple message to readers that is also one of the most profound considerations of life which is our purpose in this world.

column4: This magical book will help you to find the hidden magic within you ‚ù§Ô∏è
column5:
This is a philosophical fictional but you can considered it as a spiritual, motivational, inspirational, self help book which will definitely gonna change your life.

It book is about a shepherd boy named Santigo & his journey to find his destiny(treasure).His journey is so magical,soulful & spiritual.

This book will teach you about love, believe,following your dreams & following your heart & many more.You will get to know about some unknown but very interesting terms like Omen, Maktub,Universal Language.

This is a so well narrated book,you actually can feel every line.

It will drag you beyond your existence & you have to read this book by our soul then you will enjoy the soulful journey of Santigo & will learn to live life soulfully.

The quality of the paper is not much good but it's okay.Font size of the para is readable but when the words in a paper are written very thick then it's problematic to read and in this most of the times you'll see this kind of trend (only some pages are not too much bold/thick but they are plain and readable).So my endping point is that paper quality is not much good and sometimes you may get headache.

Talking about the book is it's amazing to read and each page of the book is worth to read it again for full motivation basically which lifts you in the mood of positivity,and you'll start to ask some fascinating questions about yourself and the the world.It sometimes moves you in the zone of spirituality but everyone has their ideal of worship to follow to reach the destination hub.I've got some favorite quotes from the book that are Worth mentioning but here I'll disclose only one :
"If you can concentrate always on the present,you'll be a happy man.life is the moment we're living right now".
Finally The book should be in your bookshelf.

The paper used is the sort that government schools use to print their question papers, it will tear at the slightest of tugs. I don't recommend you buy this just because of the terrible quality.\n

I have special interest in History as i love it as subject. I have read many history books not only modern but also ancient or books on prehistory. But after reading Homosapiens i am just overwhelmed that how the author has presented evolution of human history in such a simplistic , unique and analytical manner.
 This book not only details anthropological evidences or facts but it covers all scenarios to present the picture whether it is biology, genetics, culture, science , environment etc.
I loved the way the author covered the issue and aspects of religion in human history from early man till today. How and why religion evolved , and how religion is directly related to political and economic power.
This book will help you in critical analysis of what we are fed or what we study. This book will force you to form your opinion based on facts and logic rather than some religion or superstitions. Some of the best chapters in the book are:
1 History biggest fraud
2 There is no justice in history
3 The law of religion
4 The marriage of Science and
 Empires
5 The End of Homosapiens.

This book is must read for not only student of history but for all those who are curious enough to understand the concept of how human history evolved.

BOOK SPECIFICATIONS :
1 Book : Sapiens
2 Author : Yuval Noah Harari
3 Language : English
4 Year : 2015
5 Publisher : Penguin
6 Parts/Chapters : 5/20

SAPIENS by Yuval Noah Harari is one of the most important books of the 21st century. It is an eye opener and as informative as it can get. Harari has literally compiled all the information about our planet and our species and put it in this book. It tells us of the reason why the world that we live in today is the way it is. This book is very informative and important and cannot be described as a casual read.
I am a quick reader. I can finish a book in a few hours or a day or two, but this book has literally taken me weeks to finish. And I don‚Äôt think it is a bad thing at all. It just contains so much information and has so much to tell that I needed time to process all that I was reading about. I would literally stop after a certain topic so I could think about it and process it all and then pick up the book again. No book, and I mean no book at all, can come up to this level of importance on the ‚Äòmust-read‚Äô scale.
It is very important for us to read this book and understand the way that we as humans have evolved in every way since existing on this planet and the consequences of our decisions on other humans, beings and most importantly, this planet.

column4: Its a Book everyone shoud be reading........
column5: \n Sapiens don't need any introduction. Its a best seller for a reason and its written in that way. Those who are interested in knowing how things happened in history and reason for the current order of the word it is the best book to start with. And at the end you will be more enlightened and aware.....kind of books I like.\n
